comment_body: For debugging purposes
apart from warm reboot use case, what are other use cases? can we get more concrete? @marian-pritsak
please change phrase "Used only" to "Valid when"
Looks Good
What if the next-hop after decap is another tunnel, but not this same tunnel where pkt is received from?  Say if the next-hop for the dst is an ecmp?
Can we increment a drop reason counter when it's dropped due to this?

> What if the next-hop after decap is another tunnel, but not this same tunnel where pkt is received from? Say if the next-hop for the dst is an ecmp?

If packet is forwarded to some other tunnel instead of the ingress tunnel then this attribute will not be applied. Only when packet loops back into the ingress tunnel then this attribute is applicable.

We prefer using
saidebugcounter.h:sai_out_drop_reason_t:SAI_OUT_DROP_REASON_TUNNEL_LOOPBACK_PACKET_DROP
As this is already existing mechanism used to debug drops, and in specific tunnel drops, in sonic

> We prefer using
> saidebugcounter.h:sai_out_drop_reason_t:SAI_OUT_DROP_REASON_TUNNEL_LOOPBACK_PACKET_DROP
> As this is already existing mechanism used to debug drops, and in specific tunnel drops, in sonic

https://github.com/opencomputeproject/SAI/pull/1152/commits/cd25c2f8c515c7aac45c573a2f6cf567dfb995e8


Done

the pr looks good to me. suggestion debuggability can be another pr, not necessarily to be couple with this pr. the point is that the debuggability improvement should not change the signature of current dma allocation api. @JaiOCP , can you have a quick sync. we plan to include this pr in the v1.7.0 release.

During the review meeting we discussed about if the Tx DMA can be improved in a future PR to allow caller to specify "priority".  I believe BRCM suggested that it could be achieved by pre-allocate some DMA buffer for those high priority senders so that it will not need to compete the buffer allocation with the low priority senders.  But I feel that having different Tx priority Queues will still benefit the case where let's say there are multiple low priority senders running in a multi-threaded environment where each one wants to send a lengthy packet.  If we do have different priority queue then SAI could let the high priority sender to "cut to the front of the line" and proceed to Tx that one first before other lower priority send requests.  Again,. this comment is not meant to ask this PR to implement it but just to solicit further comment over this idea that we briefly discussed over the meeting.
Thanks!
@gechiang , thanks for the comment. maybe it is better to create an issue for the topic you discussed above.

just curious how port can be multiple interface types at once ?

This PR allows for provisioning and advertising a list of multiple IEEE ethernet protocols on a port. Linux ethtool can be used as a reference:

```
       advertise N
                  Sets the speed and duplex advertised by autonegotiation.  The argument is a hexadecimal value using one or a combination of the fol-
                  lowing values:

                  0x001             10baseT Half
                  0x002             10baseT Full
                  0x004             100baseT Half
                  0x008             100baseT Full
                  0x010             1000baseT Half           (not supported by IEEE standards)
                  0x020             1000baseT Full
                  0x20000           1000baseKX Full
                  0x20000000000     1000baseX Full
                  0x800000000000    2500baseT Full
                  0x8000            2500baseX Full           (not supported by IEEE standards)
                  0x1000000000000   5000baseT Full
                  0x1000            10000baseT Full
                  0x40000           10000baseKX4 Full
                  0x80000           10000baseKR Full
                  0x40000000000     10000baseCR  Full
                  0x80000000000     10000baseSR  Full
                  0x100000000000    10000baseLR  Full
                  0x200000000000    10000baseLRM Full
                  0x400000000000    10000baseER  Full
                  0x200000          20000baseMLD2 Full       (not supported by IEEE standards)
                  0x400000          20000baseKR2 Full        (not supported by IEEE standards)
                  0x80000000        25000baseCR Full
                  0x200000000       25000baseSR Full
                  0x800000          40000baseKR4 Full
                  0x1000000         40000baseCR4 Full
                  0x2000000         40000baseSR4 Full
                  0x4000000         40000baseLR4 Full
                  0x400000000       50000baseCR2 Full
                  0x800000000       50000baseKR2 Full
                  0x10000000000     50000baseSR2 Full
                  0x8000000         56000baseKR4 Full
                  0x10000000        56000baseCR4 Full
                  0x20000000        56000baseSR4 Full
                  0x40000000        56000baseLR4 Full
                  0x1000000000      100000baseKR4 Full
                  0x2000000000      100000baseSR4 Full
                  0x4000000000      100000baseCR4 Full
                  0x8000000000      100000baseLR4_ER4 Full
```

SONiC 202006 is using SAI 1.6.3 and hence we shall use only the 1.6.3 release notes and ignore the 1.6.5 release notes. We have addressed all the review comments given in the [PR1134](https://github.com/opencomputeproject/SAI/pull/1134) meant for 1.6.5 in this 1.6.3 release notes. Request you to review this PR and sign off.

****Review Comments from PR1134 applicable for SAI 1.6.3**** 

@bandaru-viswanath 
>>(1) I think the saitunnel.h has more diffs, than what is presented here.

Reply :  We have added more details. Request you to kindly check and confirm.

@michaelli10 
>>(1) Does it make sense to separate the changes by feature similar to SAI 1.5 release notes for context? Also, adding the PR references would be helpful. https://github.com/opencomputeproject/SAI/blob/v1.6/doc/SAI_1.5_ReleaseNotes.md

Reply : Yes, We have revamped the SAI 1.6.3 release notes. We also added the list of features mentioned by @rlhui in this rel notes. Request you to kindly check and confirm.

>> (2) Is the SAI_LAG_ATTR_TPID attribute intentionally included?

Reply :  Yes, as it is included in the new SAI 1.6.3 release tag.

>> (3) Will you add the system port changes (and other saiport.h changes) from [PR#1080](https://github.com/opencomputeproject/SAI/pull/1080) [PR#1081](https://github.com/opencomputeproject/SAI/pull/1081) ?

Reply :  Yes, the revamped document covers the new APIs and its additional changes which are part of [PR#1081](https://github.com/opencomputeproject/SAI/pull/1081) , however [PR#1080](https://github.com/opencomputeproject/SAI/pull/1080) is not part of this SAI 1.6.3 release tag. Kindly suggest if we need to add the [PR#1080](https://github.com/opencomputeproject/SAI/pull/1080) as well part of this release notes.

>> (4) Can you add an item about the new system port related attributes?
SAI_SWITCH_ATTR_SWITCH_ID
SAI_SWITCH_ATTR_MAX_SYSTEM_CORES
SAI_SWITCH_ATTR_SYSTEM_PORT_CONFIG_LIST
SAI_SWITCH_ATTR_NUMBER_OF_SYSTEM_PORTS
SAI_SWITCH_ATTR_SYSTEM_PORT_LIST
SAI_SWITCH_ATTR_NUMBER_OF_FABRIC_PORTS
SAI_SWITCH_ATTR_FABRIC_PORT_LIST

Reply :  Yes, we have added details on this. Request to kindly check and confirm.


****NOTE:** The other comments related rephrasing, typo are also addressed.** 
The comments that are given in [PR#1134](https://github.com/opencomputeproject/SAI/pull/1134) are specific to SAI 1.6.5, but not relevant to SAI 1.6.3 are ignored.

> As discussed, please consider the approach followed by saidebugcounter.h
> Specifically, the attribute:
> 
> ```
> /* READ-ONLY */
> 
> /**
>  * @brief Object stat index
>  * Index is added to base start
>  *
>  * @type sai_uint32_t
>  * @flags READ_ONLY
>  */
> SAI_DEBUG_COUNTER_ATTR_INDEX
> ```
> 
> This solves backward compatibility issues as well as doesn't waste hardware resources.
> 
> The steps should be:
> 
> 1. Create one or more UDF groups.
>    Read back the SAI_UDF_GROUP_ATTR_INDEX
>    SDK driver ensures that it returns an unique index for each UDF group.
> 
> 1. Let us say that the UDF groups of our interest have  SAI_UDF_GROUP_ATTR_INDEX values as i and j.
> 2. create ACL table with attributes:
> 
> ```
> ...
> SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_USER_DEFINED_FIELD_GROUP_MIN+i;
>     acl_attr_list[index++].value.booldata = True;
> SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_USER_DEFINED_FIELD_GROUP_MIN+j;
>     acl_attr_list[index++].value.booldata = True;
> 
> ...
> ```

This is a good idea. I will incorporate this change. Only side effect of this is that there is a state maintained in SAI driver and need to be maintained and carried across during warm boot or ISSU

This can be simplified considerably by changing SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_USER_DEFINED_FIELD_GROUP_MIN through SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_USER_DEFINED_FIELD_GROUP_MAX to use @type sai_object_id_t with @objects SAI_OBJECT_TYPE_UDF_GROUP.

At the previous SAI meeting, we saw that not all SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_FIELD_* attributes use @type bool.
Specifically, SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_FIELD_ACL_RANGE_TYPE uses @type sai_s32_list_t sai_acl_range_type_t.
While there is no current example of a SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_FIELD_* attribute using @type sai_object_id_t, IMO the precedent to use something other than @type bool implies that this should work without causing too many problems.

If you make this change, then the addition of SAI_UDF_GROUP_ATTR_INDEX is no longer necessary.
The goal of being able to determine the ACL key at table definition time can be achieved by leveraging the rest of this proposal.

> This can be simplified considerably by changing SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_USER_DEFINED_FIELD_GROUP_MIN through SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_USER_DEFINED_FIELD_GROUP_MAX to use @type sai_object_id_t with @objects SAI_OBJECT_TYPE_UDF_GROUP.
> 
> At the previous SAI meeting, we saw that not all SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_FIELD_* attributes use @type bool.
> Specifically, SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_FIELD_ACL_RANGE_TYPE uses @type sai_s32_list_t sai_acl_range_type_t.
> While there is no current example of a SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_FIELD_* attribute using @type sai_object_id_t, IMO the precedent to use something other than @type bool implies that this should work without causing too many problems.
> 
> If you make this change, then the addition of SAI_UDF_GROUP_ATTR_INDEX is no longer necessary.
> The goal of being able to determine the ACL key at table definition time can be achieved by leveraging the rest of this proposal.

Hi Mickey,

Looks like the match fields in ACL table has to be a bool datatype. I tried the change and get following error. 
Other attributes we were looking are not the match fields (between SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_FIELD_START and SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_FIELD_END) that is why they can be of other datatypes. This also means we can not change the match fields to uint8 as we were discussing. They have to be bool.

Let me know if you can think of any other way to handle this. 
...
 ASSERT FAILED (on line 3980): SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_USER_DEFINED_FIELD_GROUP_MIN: acl table attr value type should be bool
...

@JaiOCP I am not sure how to handle this, but I wonder how SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_FIELD_ACL_RANGE_TYPE got around this.
It is clearly in between SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_FIELD_START and SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_FIELD_END.

> @JaiOCP I am not sure how to handle this, but I wonder how SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_FIELD_ACL_RANGE_TYPE got around this.
> It is clearly in between SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_FIELD_START and SAI_ACL_TABLE_ATTR_FIELD_END.

I have checked in meta checker exception and updated the diffs as agreed in the review meeting. Please take a look

Changes looks good to me

> **2. Sampling using mirror and samplepacket:**
>  The mirror session object to use will be selected when the sample object is attached to a SAI port object via SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION or SAI_PORT_ATTR_EGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION port attributes.

How do we support both mirroring and sflow on the same port? SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION points to a list of Mirror objects. A packet coming in on this port is mirrored to all the mirrors in the list.   In the proposed model, how do we find which Mirror objects should be used for sflow, and which mirror objects should be used for plain mirroring? It would be better to separate it out, say something like SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_SFLOW_MIRROR_SESSION

> In the proposed model, how do we find which Mirror objects should be used for sflow, and which mirror objects should be used for plain mirroring? It would be better to separate it out, say something like

Could you clarify why do you want to treat sflow mirror different from other mirrors? There is no distinction between sflow mirror and other mirrors.

As far as I understand packet should be sent to all mirrors. Mirror only provides sampling(SAI_MIRROR_SESSION_ATTR_SAMPLE_RATE) and encapsulation properties(SAI_MIRROR_SESSION_ATTR_TYPE) and that governs outgoing packet rate and format. Sflow will have UDP, ERSPAN will have GRE, RSPAN will be Vlan tagged, SPAN will be original packet. 

Sampling decision is either at ingress or egress side or both (depending on underlying ASIC capability). 

Sampling at ingress is done by virtue of sample packet object association with port(SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_SAMPLEPACKET_ENABLE or SAI_PORT_ATTR_EGRESS_SAMPLEPACKET_ENABLE) and sample object can have sampling rate greater than 1(SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_ATTR_SAMPLE_RATE). 

Sampling at egress is done by virtue of sampling rate attribute of mirror object(SAI_MIRROR_SESSION_ATTR_SAMPLE_RATE) and the sampling rate is greater 1.

If ingress or egress sample  happening at port (SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_ATTR_SAMPLE_RATE and SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_SAMPLEPACKET_ENABLE/SAI_PORT_ATTR_EGRESS_SAMPLEPACKET_ENABLE) and sample object type is SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_TYPE_MIRROR_SESSION, only if packet is sample candidate, it should mirrored (to all mirror objects)(SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION/SAI_PORT_ATTR_EGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION).

If sampling is happening at mirror session (SAI_MIRROR_SESSION_ATTR_SAMPLE_RATE), then all mirrors should receive all packets and only those mirrors with sampling rate greater than 1, which will sample packet as per the rate. 

In short SAI_PORT_ATTR_EGRESS_SAMPLEPACKET_ENABLE and SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_ATTR_SAMPLE_RATE, it will apply to all mirror sessions of port (and each mirror session can have their own sampling rate). Otherwise mirror sessions' sampling rate should decide sample decision. If that's not desirable, don't configure SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_SAMPLEPACKET_ENABLE/SAI_PORT_ATTR_EGRESS_SAMPLEPACKET_ENABLE and configure sample rate at mirror session.

> > In the proposed model, how do we find which Mirror objects should be used for sflow, and which mirror objects should be used for plain mirroring? It would be better to separate it out, say something like
> 
> Could you clarify why do you want to treat sflow mirror different from other mirrors? There is no distinction between sflow mirror and other mirrors.
> 
> As far as I understand packet should be sent to all mirrors. Mirror only provides sampling(SAI_MIRROR_SESSION_ATTR_SAMPLE_RATE) and encapsulation properties(SAI_MIRROR_SESSION_ATTR_TYPE) and that governs outgoing packet rate and format. Sflow will have UDP, ERSPAN will have GRE, RSPAN will be Vlan tagged, SPAN will be original packet.
> 
> Sampling decision is either at ingress or egress side or both (depending on underlying ASIC capability).
> 
> Sampling at ingress is done by virtue of sample packet object association with port(SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_SAMPLEPACKET_ENABLE or SAI_PORT_ATTR_EGRESS_SAMPLEPACKET_ENABLE) and sample object can have sampling rate greater than 1(SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_ATTR_SAMPLE_RATE).
> 
> Sampling at egress is done by virtue of sampling rate attribute of mirror object(SAI_MIRROR_SESSION_ATTR_SAMPLE_RATE) and the sampling rate is greater 1.
> 
> If ingress or egress sample happening at port (SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_ATTR_SAMPLE_RATE and SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_SAMPLEPACKET_ENABLE/SAI_PORT_ATTR_EGRESS_SAMPLEPACKET_ENABLE) and sample object type is SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_TYPE_MIRROR_SESSION, only if packet is sample candidate, it should mirrored (to all mirror objects)(SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION/SAI_PORT_ATTR_EGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION).
> 
> If sampling is happening at mirror session (SAI_MIRROR_SESSION_ATTR_SAMPLE_RATE), then all mirrors should receive all packets and only those mirrors with sampling rate greater than 1, which will sample packet as per the rate.
> 
> In short SAI_PORT_ATTR_EGRESS_SAMPLEPACKET_ENABLE and SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_ATTR_SAMPLE_RATE, it will apply to all mirror sessions of port (and each mirror session can have their own sampling rate). Otherwise mirror sessions' sampling rate should decide sample decision. If that's not desirable, don't configure SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_SAMPLEPACKET_ENABLE/SAI_PORT_ATTR_EGRESS_SAMPLEPACKET_ENABLE and configure sample rate at mirror session.

The original question is about the 2nd model, viz. __Sampling using mirror and samplepacket__

I think where we both differ is that I want to support both sFlow and mirroring on the same ingress port. For example, on port p1, I have multiple mirror sessions. On some of these mirrors, I dont want sampling, and in some mirror sessions I want the same sample rate.  And I want to use the 2nd model so that I can conserve my samplers to one per port since all these use the same rate.

With the proposed model, how do we realize the above example? Having a new attribute avoids this limitation with the proposed model.

@phshaikh:  

Regarding your below description:

If ingress or egress sample happening at port (SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_ATTR_SAMPLE_RATE and SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_SAMPLEPACKET_ENABLE/SAI_PORT_ATTR_EGRESS_SAMPLEPACKET_ENABLE) and sample object type is SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_TYPE_MIRROR_SESSION, only if packet is sample candidate, it should mirrored (to all mirror objects)(SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION/SAI_PORT_ATTR_EGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION).

>>> Ideally that means if sflow is enable on port then we cannot mirror all packets. In most of ASIC Mirroring and SFLOW are two different operation and each one can have is own session/destination. We still want to mirror all packets to one session/encapsualtion and sflow some packets at given rate to another session/encapsulation 
I think that is point @rck-innovium and we brought up in meeting.

> @phshaikh:
> 
> Regarding your below description:
> 
> If ingress or egress sample happening at port (SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_ATTR_SAMPLE_RATE and SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_SAMPLEPACKET_ENABLE/SAI_PORT_ATTR_EGRESS_SAMPLEPACKET_ENABLE) and sample object type is SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_TYPE_MIRROR_SESSION, only if packet is sample candidate, it should mirrored (to all mirror objects)(SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION/SAI_PORT_ATTR_EGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION).
> 
> > > > Ideally that means if sflow is enable on port then we cannot mirror all packets. In most of ASIC Mirroring and SFLOW are two different operation and each one can have is own session/destination. We still want to mirror all packets to one session/encapsualtion and sflow some packets at given rate to another session/encapsulation
> > > > I think that is point @rck-innovium and we brought up in meeting.

Exactly.

also on top what is expectation for below case:

Port base sampling is enable and SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_TYPE_MIRROR_SESSION is configured.

a) If we have SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION point to two Session

Session 1 of type SAI_ERSPAN_ENCAPSULATION_TYPE_MIRROR_SFLOW_TUNNEL and 
Session 2 of type SAI_ERSPAN_ENCAPSULATION_TYPE_MIRROR_L3_GRE_TUNNEL

we will receive SFLOW copy on both but that is expected/desired ? since we have dedicated SFLOW Tunnel type do we still want to get Sflow copy on GRE tunnel also ? 

b) Also another question I had if mirror session  tunnel type is SAI_ERSPAN_ENCAPSULATION_TYPE_MIRROR_SFLOW_TUNNEL do we want to support SAI_MIRROR_SESSION_ATTR_SAMPLE_RATE for that session ? If we can configure then we have Sampling 2 times and am not sure that can be supported.

@rck-innovium 

>The original question is about the 2nd model, viz. Sampling using mirror and samplepacket

>I think where we both differ is that I want to support both sFlow and mirroring on the same >ingress port. For example, on port p1, I have multiple mirror sessions. On some of these >mirrors, I dont want sampling, and in some mirror sessions I want the same sample rate. And I >want to use the 2nd model so that I can conserve my samplers to one per port since all these >use the same rate.

>With the proposed model, how do we realize the above example? Having a new attribute >avoids this limitation with the proposed model.

Sorry, if I missed but which attribute are you proposing?

@abdosi @rck-innovium 
>Ideally that means if sflow is enable on port then we cannot mirror all packets. In most of ASIC >Mirroring and SFLOW are two different operation and each one can have is own >session/destination. We still want to mirror all packets to one session/encapsualtion and sflow >some packets at given rate to another session/encapsulation
>I think that is point @rck-innovium and we brought up in meeting.

"sflow" here is an encapsulation format (mainly UDP + any other implementation defined metadata) and not any specific operation. Sampling at the source is an operation represented by sample packet object. Set up sample packet object with sample rate of 1 and use sample rate attribute of mirror session. Does that help? It allows you to set up multiple mirrors while some mirrors sending all traffic while one with mirror with sample rate sending traffic as per sample rate.

@phshaikh, Sorry may be I am missing some thing here. Basic Question using SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_ATTR_TYPE = SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_TYPE_MIRROR_SESSION means what ? As I understand once we do that we start using mirror destinations define by SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION  (ingress direction) as sflow copy destination (which is as of now default to CPU only) Is it correct ?

I think from your perspective SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION  can use by two application sflow and mirroring simultaneously. when being used in mirroring context all packets will be mirrored and in using sflow context only sample packets will be sent. Is it true ? 

 


>also on top what is expectation for below case:
>
>Port base sampling is enable and SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_TYPE_MIRROR_SESSION is configured.
>
>a) If we have SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION point to two Session
>
>Session 1 of type SAI_ERSPAN_ENCAPSULATION_TYPE_MIRROR_SFLOW_TUNNEL and
>Session 2 of type SAI_ERSPAN_ENCAPSULATION_TYPE_MIRROR_L3_GRE_TUNNEL

>we will receive SFLOW copy on both but that is expected/desired ? since we have dedicated >SFLOW Tunnel type do we still want to get Sflow copy on GRE tunnel also ?

Why will there be "SFLOW" copy? Both mirrors will get original packet and will encapsulate as per their own properties or attributes. SFLOW_TUNNEL mirror will emit packet with sflow/udp encapsulation and L3_GRE_TUNNEL mirror will emit packet with gre encapsulation. 



>b) Also another question I had if mirror session tunnel type is >SAI_ERSPAN_ENCAPSULATION_TYPE_MIRROR_SFLOW_TUNNEL do we want to support >SAI_MIRROR_SESSION_ATTR_SAMPLE_RATE for that session ? If we can configure then we >have Sampling 2 times and am not sure that can be supported.

There are ASIC which support setting sample rate at mirror. It is upto underlying adapter to verify configuration and throw invalid parameter error if it can not accept configuration which application wants. Whether to use sample rate from sample object or from mirror object is also entirely prerogative of underlying implementation. Spec has to be as generic as possible to allow different vendors to implement sampling with different encapsulation (sflow being one of them).
@abdosi it would be better if you post new comments with markdown formatting, Now i am totally lost which one is your comment and which one is mine since i think you edited my comment :-)

@abdosi 

Assuming this is from you :-)

>@phshaikh, Sorry may be I am missing some thing here. Basic Question using SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_ATTR_TYPE = SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_TYPE_MIRROR_SESSION means what ? As I understand once we do that we start using mirror destinations define by SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION (ingress direction) as sflow copy destination (which is as of now default to CPU only) Is it correct ?

SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_TYPE_MIRROR_SESSION means a sample (original packet) should be sent to mirror. There is no "encapsulation" indication here. Also I don't think spec specifies that sample is sent "encapsulated" in sflow to CPU for SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_TYPE_SLOW_PATH. In most cases, ASIC sends packet as is to CPU and application is expected to do sflow encapsulation. Here SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_TYPE_MIRROR_SESSION means, instead of sending to CPU, send it to mirror and let mirror's encap property govern encapsulation.

>I think from your perspective SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION can use by two application sflow and mirroring simultaneously. when being used in mirroring context all packets will be mirrored and in using sflow context only sample packets will be sent. Is it true ?

SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION is mirror (or list of mirrors) associated with port which mirror "ingress" traffic.

Consider this as pseudo code of SAI objects

```
sai_mirror {SFLOW} // mirror object
sample_object {SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_TYPE_MIRROR_SESSION} // sample object to mirror
sai_port {SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_SAMPLEPACKET_ENABLE : sample_object, } // sample to mirrors
sai_port{SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION: sai_mirror} // list of mirrors to sample to
```

This means application created mirror of SFLOW type, associated it with port. And if sai_port is also using sample object of type, SAI_SAMPLEPACKET_TYPE_MIRROR_SESSION, sampled packets will go to sai_mirror object.

If there're more than one mirror, all those mirrors will get sampled packet

In your model, 
1) does the new attribute belong to sample packet object or port object? 
2) is the new attribute going to be list of mirrors or just one mirror to receive samples?

The existing model is simpler in which sampled traffic goes to all mirrors but in the new model, sampled traffic goes to subset of mirrors (identified) by new attribute while un-sampled traffic goes to other mirrors. @srikrishnagopu I also feel we need another attribute here.

I was hoping to discuss this in today's meeting but we ran out of time. Please see inline.


> SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_SAMPLE_MIRROR_SESSION



> > > @rck-innovium
> > > > With the proposed model, how do we realize the above example? Having a new attribute >avoids this limitation with the proposed model.
> > > 
> > > 
> > > Sorry, if I missed but which attribute are you proposing?
> > 
> > 
> > Pls refer to the last sentence of my first comment. SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_SFLOW_MIRROR_SESSION.
> > And I was wrong to use the term sFlow instead of sampling. I am rephrasing my original comment:
> > How do we support both mirroring and sampling on the same port? SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION points to a list of Mirror objects. A packet coming in on this port is mirrored to all the mirrors in the list. In the proposed model, how do we find which Mirror objects should be used for sampling, and which mirror objects should be used for plain mirroring without sampling? It would be better to separate it out, say something like SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_SAMPLE_MIRROR_SESSION
> 
> In your model,
> 
> 1. does the new attribute belong to sample packet object or port object?


**SAI_PORT_ATTR**_INGRESS_SAMPLE_MIRROR_SESSION  => it is a SAI Port object attribute

> 2. is the new attribute going to be list of mirrors or just one mirror to receive samples?

A list of mirrors. An OID list same as SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION.

> 3. will the same mirror objects exist in both attributes - new attribute and port's list of mirror sessions?

It is upto the user but reasonable to see that it will be in only one list.

> 4. what do we gain with this model? The existing model is simpler in which sampled traffic goes to all mirrors but in the new model, sampled traffic goes to subset of mirrors (identified) by new attribute while un-sampled traffic goes to other mirrors. 


The new model is simple if you just use SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_SAMPLE_MIRROR_SESSION instead of SAI_PORT_ATTR_INGRESS_MIRROR_SESSION. Whatever you had suggested will work.

The advantage with having this new attribute is for those devices that can support the case where traffic coming in on a port can be sampled for certain destinations, and sent out unsampled for other destinations. 
Also, it does not change the behavior for existing implementations.

> It also calls for differentiated treatment both in application and in adapter code among mirrors based on which should get sampled traffic vs unsampled traffic. @srikrishnagopu / @JaiOCP  your thoughts on this?

They are two different sessions, so they can go to two different applications. One application can be an sflow collector and the other application a mirror collector.

also in CL there is a path to find right LAG using other members like LAG_MEMBERs and ports, this is called pre-match logic, and works well, and finds correct lags

> @marian-pritsak
> Why not use the UDF infrastructure. It provides same functionality, isn't it?
> UDF match rules are based on sai_acl_field_data_t for L2 and L3 fields and can be arbitrarily combined to create a complex rule for hash.

The UDF match object is very limited - you can classify only by Ethertype, IP type, GRE type.
It does not cover anything related to tunnels and inner headers or other packet fields. Instead of defining the match all over again, the better way is to just use what ACL has.

SAI inseg entry attribute `SAI_INSEG_ENTRY_ATTR_PACKET_ACTION` can also be configured to trap packet to the CPU. Do you want to add the trap ID for those trapped packets too?

Otherwise, it looks OK

I believe I can add a trap id for that as well, while we're at it. 

Do you mind double checking if the value of these MPLS traps are okay? 

SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_STATIC_FDB_MOVE has 0x00006002 value and then next one SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_PIPELINE_DISCARD_EGRESS_BUFFER  is jumped to 0x00007000.

Should I be putting it before 0x00007000 or the current values look okay?
Applied comments

> > SAI inseg entry attribute `SAI_INSEG_ENTRY_ATTR_PACKET_ACTION` can also be configured to trap packet to the CPU. Do you want to add the trap ID for those trapped packets too?
> > Otherwise, it looks OK
> 
> I believe I can add a trap id for that as well, while we're at it.
> 
> Do you mind double checking if the value of these MPLS traps are okay?
> 
> SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_STATIC_FDB_MOVE has 0x00006002 value and then next one SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_PIPELINE_DISCARD_EGRESS_BUFFER is jumped to 0x00007000.
> 
> Should I be putting it before 0x00007000 or the current values look okay?

Yeah, the 0x00007000 range is related to buffer and other non-lookup drops. I'd suggest starting a new range for MPLS - 0x00009000.

Another thing - `SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_MPLS_INSEG_ENTRY_TO_CPU` shouldn't be the part of `sai_hostif_trap_type_t` because it is caused by the packet_action of the inseg entry installed by a user. Such traps go to the `sai_hostif_user_defined_trap_type_t` and should be called something like `SAI_HOSTIF_USER_DEFINED_TRAP_TYPE_MPLS`.

> > SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_MPLS_INSEG_ENTRY_TO_CPU
> 
> @marian-pritsak 0x9000 is SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_END, I don't know if I should be touching _END and 0x8000 is SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_CUSTOM_EXCEPTION_RANGE_BASE.
> 
> So I picked 0x7500 - 0x8000 for MPLS, let me know if its okay to pick 0x9000, I don't mind one way or other

You can assign SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_END to 0xa000, and MPLS to 0x9000

> > > SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_MPLS_INSEG_ENTRY_TO_CPU
> > 
> > 
> > @marian-pritsak 0x9000 is SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_END, I don't know if I should be touching _END and 0x8000 is SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_CUSTOM_EXCEPTION_RANGE_BASE.
> > So I picked 0x7500 - 0x8000 for MPLS, let me know if its okay to pick 0x9000, I don't mind one way or other
> 
> You can assign SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_END to 0xa000, and MPLS to 0x9000

Will do :) Thanks

> You can assign SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_END to 0xa000, and MPLS to 0x9000

SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_CUSTOM_EXCEPTION_RANGE_BASE should be move after MPLS.

> > You can assign SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_END to 0xa000, and MPLS to 0x9000
> 
> SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_CUSTOM_EXCEPTION_RANGE_BASE should be move after MPLS.

would that be backward compatible? since range is pushed ahead?

> > > You can assign SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_END to 0xa000, and MPLS to 0x9000
> > 
> > 
> > SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_CUSTOM_EXCEPTION_RANGE_BASE should be move after MPLS.
> 
> would that be backward compatible? since range is pushed ahead?

It will since the enum names are not changed.
MPLS -> 0x8000
SAI_HOSTIF_TRAP_TYPE_CUSTOM_EXCEPTION_RANGE_BASE -> 0x9000
it is not binary backward compatible, but if the user recompile their application with the new SAI header, it will work.

Have you checked this? https://github.com/opencomputeproject/SAI/pull/696
In this case when a static move is detected the application will be notified and it can re-program the static MAC on the port.

> Have you checked this? #696
> In this case when a static move is detected the application will be notified and it can re-program the static MAC on the port.

696 is after a static move is detected. Here the setting is to allow for a static move as described in the previous reply.

> Have you checked this? #696
> In this case when a static move is detected the application will be notified and it can re-program the static MAC on the port.

The #696 has a trap type added for static fdb mac move. 
   However I do not see the SAI_SWITCH_ATTR_STATIC_FDB_MOVE_PACKET_ACTION     merged to saiswitch.h though it is mentioned in the PR. 

   I am not sure if this was intentional. Without this the added trap  does not seem to make sense. 
 
   The above packet action even if added is a switch wide attribute which is applicable to locally configured static MACs as well. We may not want this and would like to 
   differentiate from an EVPN MAC.  In other words we would like a drop if there is a mac move experienced for a local static but at the same time would like to 
   allow EVPN MACs to be subjected to MAC Move. 

   The EVPN remote macs though programmed as static are not the same as locally configured static MACs. These are dynamically learnt MACs on a remote 
   switch.
